title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam in the 7th century CE?
What was the name of the city that became the political heart of the empire formed by Muhammad?
Who became the new caliph after Muhammad's death and emerged victorious from a contentious question among those close to him?
What was the name of the dynasty that came to power after the fourth caliph, Ali, was assassinated?
What was the name of the city built by the Abbasid family as the new capital after they overthrew the Umayyad caliphate in 750 CE?
What was the result of the extensive trade networks that brought products and people from all over the known world to Baghdad under Abbasid rule?
What was the main issue with the succession of the caliph under Abbasid rule?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of clear line of succession

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Mongols approaching Baghdad in 1258 CE?

options.label: A
options.text: The city was rebuilt and became an even greater center of learning

options.label: B
options.text: The caliph was overthrown and the empire was divided

options.label: D
options.text: The empire was unified under a new ruler

multiple-choice.question: What was the lasting mark left by the Islamic Empire on the world?

options.label: B
options.text: The establishment of the Mongol Empire

options.label: C
options.text: The spread of Islam and the ideas of its greatest intellectuals

multiple-choice.question: What was the reality that the siege of Baghdad laid bare?

options.label: A
options.text: The caliphs had ruled with absolute power

options.label: B
options.text: The empire was united under a single ruler

options.label: C
options.text: Local leaders throughout the empire had grown more powerful and refused to pay taxes

options.label: D
options.text: The empire was on the brink of collapse

options.label: D
options.text: To remove any damage or alterations to the painting

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: To recreate the missing sections of the painting

options.label: B
options.text: To conceal the original subject's face

options.label: C
options.text: To reveal the original paint layers and composition

options.label: D
options.text: To remove any damage or alterations to the painting

options.label: A
options.text: Art restoration involves improving the painting, while art conservation involves preserving the original work

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: A brief history of Spanish - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the colloquial spoken Latin that mixed with Indigenous languages during the Roman occupation of the Iberian Peninsula?
What percentage of modern Spanish comes from Latin?

options.label: A
options.text: The Indigenous population of the Americas was able to maintain their languages and cultures.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The Spanish language was lost in the Americas.

options.label: D
options.text: The Spanish language was not affected by the conquest.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: French replaced Spanish as the official language.

options.label: C
options.text: Spanish lost its influence in the Americas.

options.label: D
options.text: French and Spanish became distinct languages.

title: This weird trick will help you summon an army of worms - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the tradition where people use a metal strip or a fork to summon earthworms?

options.label: A
options.text: "The Formation of Vegetable Mould, Through the Action of Worms, with Observations on their Habits"

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: D

title: The true cost of gold - Lyla Latif

options.label: B
options.text: Corruption on an individual, corporate, and national scale

options.label: B

title: The 4 greatest threats to the survival of humanity

multiple-choice.question: In January 1995, Russia detected a nuclear missile headed its way, but it was actually a research rocket studying the Northern Lights.

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of a nuclear winter

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of a global pandemic

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of a supervolcano eruption

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of a global economic collapse

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated rate of natural existential risk per century?
What is one of the emerging technologies that poses an existential risk?
What is the estimated anthropogenic existential risk compared to the background rate of natural risk?
What is the primary concern associated with superintelligent AI?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of a nuclear war

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of a global pandemic

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of a nuclear winter

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of the AI system not being perfectly aligned with human values

options.text: A slight increase in global temperatures

options.label: B
options.text: A significant decrease in global temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: The failure of crops that humanity depends on

options.label: B
options.text: A significant increase in global temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: A calamity of possibly unprecedented proportions

options.label: D
options.text: A slight decrease in global temperatures

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of reducing the anthropogenic existential risk?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the risk of a nuclear war

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the risk of a nuclear winter

options.label: D

title: What’s the best country to live in?

multiple-choice.question: Who invented the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the 1930s?

options.label: A
options.text: GDP takes into account education, while Gross National Happiness does not

options.label: B
options.text: GDP takes into account health, while Gross National Happiness does not

options.label: C
options.text: GDP does not take into account what a country produces or who has access to it, while Gross National Happiness does

options.label: D
options.text: GDP is calculated by dividing the total GDP by the number of people living in a country, while Gross National Happiness is calculated by multiplying the total GDP by the number of people living in a country

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: It is less accurate than a single number

options.label: A
options.text: It is too complex and difficult to understand

options.label: B
options.text: It does not take into account multiple factors that are important for well-being

options.label: C
options.text: It is less accurate than a more nuanced approach

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to most people's lives

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It has managed to grow its economy and improve living standards substantially without drastically increasing its emissions

options.label: D
options.text: It has relied heavily on fossil fuels

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index takes into account income per capita, while the Human Development Index does not

options.label: C
options.text: The Human Development Index takes into account environmental burdens, while the Sustainable Development Index does not

options.label: D
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index takes into account environmental burdens, while the Human Development Index does not

options.label: B

title: The British Museum is full of stolen artifacts

multiple-choice.question: What is the British Museum primarily known for?

options.label: B
options.text: Its extensive collection of cultural and historical artifacts from around the world

options.text: Its emphasis on ancient Greek and Roman history

options.label: A
options.text: They are too valuable to be displayed

options.label: B
options.text: They are too fragile to be handled

options.label: B
options.text: The British soldiers were accused of looting the palace

options.label: C
options.text: The Kingdom of Benin refused to comply with British trade demands

options.label: D
options.text: The British government decided to annex the Kingdom of Benin

options.text: To retrieve the treasures from the palace of the King of Benin

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are a visual archive of the Kingdom of Benin's history and culture

options.label: D
options.text: They are a symbol of British colonial power

options.label: B
options.text: They are willing to lend cultural property to other museums, including those in Nigeria

options.label: C

options.text: It marks the beginning of a new era of cooperation between the British Museum and the Kingdom of Benin

options.label: B
options.text: The gain of cultural heritage and identity

options.label: C
options.text: The transfer of cultural property from one country to another

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of new cultural artifacts

options.label: A
options.text: To preserve the cultural heritage of the past

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To begin the necessary task and project of cultural reconstitution

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What happened to a parrot that spoke with the same British accent as its owner in 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: It lost its British accent and began chattering in Spanish.

options.label: B
options.text: It gained a new species-specific call.

options.label: C
options.text: It became mute and never spoke again.

options.label: D
options.text: It developed a unique vocalization that it used to communicate with its owner.

multiple-choice.question: Why do parrots use sophisticated mimicry?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract mates and defend their territory.

options.label: B
options.text: To communicate with other parrots in their flock.

options.label: C
options.text: To learn and imitate a wide range of sounds, including the human voice.

multiple-choice.question: Where is the sound produced in a parrot's vocalization?

options.label: A
options.text: In the larynx, located at the top of its windpipe.

options.label: B
options.text: In the syrinx, located at the base of its windpipe.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a parrot's tongue?

options.label: A
options.text: It is very rigid and unable to move.

options.label: B
options.text: It is very flexible and powerful, helping them manipulate seeds and nuts.

options.label: C
options.text: It is very small and not visible.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used for eating.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of a parrot's beak?
What is unique about a parrot's brain compared to other birds?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a single song system.

options.label: B
options.text: It has an additional circuit that allows for extra flexibility when learning calls.

options.label: C
options.text: It is smaller than other birds.

options.label: D
options.text: It is less developed than other birds.

multiple-choice.question: What do captive parrots often attempt to do when they talk?

options.label: A
options.text: Form social bonds with other parrots.

options.label: C
options.text: Form social bonds in the absence of their own species.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a parrot that has been observed to say things in the appropriate contexts?

options.label: C
options.text: A parrot that only says "good morning".

multiple-choice.question: What is a threat to wild parrot populations?
Why is it important to study parrots in the wild?

options.label: A
options.text: To learn about their behavior in captivity.

options.label: C
options.text: To preserve and study them in their natural habitat.
